questions.question_text: Which of the following is the defining characteristic of a scalar quantity?

options.label: A
options.text: It has both magnitude and a specific direction.

options.label: B
options.text: It is always expressed as a positive number.

options.label: C
options.text: It is expressed completely by its magnitude and a unit.

options.label: D
options.text: It follows vector addition rules.

questions.key_concept: Scalar quantity definition

questions.question_text: Identify the scalar quantity from the list below.

options.label: A
options.text: Force

options.label: B
options.text: Displacement

options.label: C
options.text: Work

options.label: D
options.text: Acceleration

questions.key_concept: Identification of scalars

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about scalars is a common misconception?

options.label: A
options.text: Scalar quantities have only magnitude.

options.label: B
options.text: Scalar quantities can be added arithmetically.

options.label: C
options.text: Speed is a scalar while velocity is a vector.

options.label: D
options.text: Scalar quantities must always be positive.

questions.key_concept: Scalars can be positive or negative (e.g., temperature).

questions.question_text: If a car travels 50 km north and then 30 km south, what is the total distance traveled?

options.label: A
options.text: 20 km

options.label: B
options.text: 80 km

options.label: C
options.text: 50 km

options.label: D
options.text: 30 km

questions.key_concept: Distance is a scalar, independent of direction.

questions.question_text: How does the addition of scalar quantities fundamentally differ from the addition of vector quantities?

options.label: A
options.text: Scalars are added using trigonometry, while vectors are added arithmetically.

options.label: B
options.text: Scalars are added considering only magnitude, while vectors require consideration of both magnitude and direction.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no fundamental difference; both follow the same rules.

options.label: D
options.text: Scalars can be subtracted but not added, while vectors can be added but not subtracted.

questions.key_concept: Scalar vs Vector addition

questions.question_text: Why is mass considered a scalar quantity, while weight is considered a vector quantity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because mass is measured in kilograms and weight in newtons.

options.label: B
options.text: Because mass has only magnitude, while weight has both magnitude (force) and direction (towards the earth's center).

options.label: C
options.text: Because mass depends on gravity, while weight does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Because mass can be zero, but weight cannot be zero.

questions.key_concept: Scalar vs Vector distinction based on directional dependency.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum required information to completely specify a vector quantity?

options.label: A
options.text: Magnitude only

options.label: B
options.text: Magnitude, unit, and direction

options.label: C
options.text: Unit and numerical value only

options.label: D
options.text: Direction only

questions.key_concept: Vector quantity definition

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a vector quantity?

options.label: A
options.text: Time

options.label: B
options.text: Density

options.label: C
options.text: Velocity

options.label: D
options.text: Energy

questions.key_concept: Identification of vectors

questions.question_text: Which statement about vectors is a trap based on a common misconception?

options.label: A
options.text: The magnitude of a vector is always positive.

options.label: B
options.text: A negative sign with a vector indicates opposite direction.

options.label: C
options.text: Displacement is a vector.

options.label: D
options.text: Vectors follow the triangle law of addition.

questions.key_concept: Magnitude is positive; sign indicates direction.

questions.question_text: A car moves 4 km East and then 3 km North. What is the magnitude of its displacement?

options.label: A
options.text: 7 km

options.label: B
options.text: 5 km

options.label: C
options.text: 1 km

options.label: D
options.text: 12 km

questions.key_concept: Displacement magnitude using Pythagoras theorem.

questions.question_text: How is the meaning of a negative sign different for a scalar like temperature versus a vector like velocity?

options.label: A
options.text: For a scalar, a negative sign means a value less than zero; for a vector, it means a magnitude less than zero.

options.label: B
options.text: For a scalar, a negative sign means a value less than zero; for a vector, it indicates a direction opposite to the chosen positive direction.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no difference; a negative sign always means 'less than'.

options.label: D
options.text: A negative sign is not used with vectors.

questions.key_concept: Interpretation of negative sign in scalars vs vectors.

questions.question_text: Why can the displacement of a body be zero even after it has traveled a certain distance?

options.label: A
options.text: Because displacement is a scalar quantity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because distance is always less than or equal to displacement.

options.label: C
options.text: Because displacement depends only on the initial and final positions. If they coincide, displacement is zero.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the speed of the body becomes zero.

questions.key_concept: Displacement is path independent.

concepts.concept_name: Rest and Motion (Definitions and Frames of Reference)

questions.question_text: A body is said to be at rest when:

options.label: A
options.text: It is not visible to the observer.

options.label: B
options.text: Its velocity is zero.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not change its position with respect to its surroundings (or a chosen reference point).

options.label: D
options.text: It is on the surface of the Earth.

questions.key_concept: Definition of rest

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of one-dimensional (rectilinear) motion?

options.label: A
options.text: A satellite orbiting Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: A car turning on a curved road.

options.label: C
options.text: A stone falling vertically downwards.

options.label: D
options.text: A butterfly flying in a garden.

questions.key_concept: Identification of one-dimensional motion

questions.question_text: Which statement about rest and motion is a common trap?

options.label: A
options.text: Rest and motion are absolute states.

options.label: B
options.text: Rest and motion are relative to a chosen frame of reference.

options.label: C
options.text: A body can be in motion for one observer and at rest for another.

options.label: D
options.text: The state of rest or motion depends on the observer's point of view.

questions.key_concept: Rest and motion are relative, not absolute.

questions.question_text: A passenger sitting in a moving train looks at a tree outside. For the passenger, the tree is:

options.label: A
options.text: At rest

options.label: B
options.text: In motion

options.label: C
options.text: Sometimes at rest, sometimes in motion

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be determined

questions.key_concept: Application of relative motion (train as reference).

questions.question_text: How does the concept of a 'point particle' simplify the study of motion?

options.label: A
options.text: It considers the internal structure of the body.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows us to ignore the size and shape of the body when the distance travelled is much larger than its size.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the body massless.

options.label: D
options.text: It restricts motion to one dimension only.

questions.key_concept: Idealization of a body as a point particle.

questions.question_text: Why is it stated that 'nothing is at absolute rest'?

options.label: A
options.text: Because all bodies are invisible at the atomic level.

options.label: B
options.text: Because every object in the universe, including Earth, stars, and galaxies, is in a state of motion.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the concept of rest is not defined in physics.

options.label: D
options.text: Because a body at rest has zero energy.

questions.key_concept: Absoluteness of motion in the universe.

questions.question_text: What is the definition of distance travelled by a body?

options.label: A
options.text: The straight-line length from initial to final position.

options.label: B
options.text: The total length of the path traversed by the body.

options.label: C
options.text: The change in position per unit time.

options.label: D
options.text: The shortest route between two points.

questions.key_concept: Definition of distance

questions.question_text: Identify the vector quantity from the pair: Distance and Displacement.

options.label: A
options.text: Distance

options.label: B
options.text: Displacement

options.label: C
options.text: Both are vectors

options.label: D
options.text: Neither is a vector

questions.key_concept: Displacement is a vector, distance is a scalar.

questions.question_text: Which statement is a trap regarding the relationship between distance and displacement?

options.label: A
options.text: The magnitude of displacement can be greater than the distance.

options.label: B
options.text: The magnitude of displacement is always less than or equal to the distance.

options.label: C
options.text: For motion in a straight line without change in direction, distance equals the magnitude of displacement.

options.label: D
options.text: Displacement can be zero even if distance is not zero.

questions.key_concept: Displacement magnitude is never greater than distance.

questions.question_text: A body moves 8 m East and then 6 m West. What is the total distance travelled and the magnitude of displacement?

options.label: A
options.text: Distance = 14 m, Displacement = 14 m East

options.label: B
options.text: Distance = 2 m, Displacement = 14 m

options.label: C
options.text: Distance = 14 m, Displacement = 2 m East

options.label: D
options.text: Distance = 14 m, Displacement = 2 m West

questions.key_concept: Calculating distance and displacement in opposite directions.

questions.question_text: In what key aspect does the algebraic treatment of distance differ from that of displacement?

options.label: A
options.text: Distance can be negative, displacement cannot.

options.label: B
options.text: Distance is always positive, displacement can be positive, negative, or zero.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are always positive.

options.label: D
options.text: Both can be negative depending on direction.

questions.key_concept: Sign convention for distance vs displacement.

questions.question_text: Why is displacement considered a more useful quantity than distance in defining velocity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because displacement is easier to measure.

options.label: B
options.text: Because velocity is defined as rate of change of displacement, which gives both speed and direction of motion.

options.label: C
options.text: Because distance is always longer, making calculations complex.

options.label: D
options.text: Because displacement is a scalar, making the formula simpler.

questions.key_concept: Velocity is a vector derived from displacement.

questions.question_text: Speed is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: Distance travelled in a particular direction per unit time.

options.label: B
options.text: The total displacement per unit time.

options.label: C
options.text: The rate of change of distance with time.

options.label: D
options.text: The rate of change of velocity with time.

questions.key_concept: Definition of speed

questions.question_text: A body covering equal distances in equal intervals of time is said to have:

options.label: A
options.text: Uniform velocity

options.label: B
options.text: Uniform speed

options.label: C
options.text: Variable acceleration

options.label: D
options.text: Non-uniform speed

questions.key_concept: Identification of uniform speed

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a trap regarding speed?

options.label: A
options.text: Instantaneous speed is measured over a very short time interval.

options.label: B
options.text: Average speed is total distance divided by total time.

options.label: C
options.text: Speed can be negative.

options.label: D
options.text: Speed is a scalar quantity.

questions.key_concept: Speed is always positive; velocity can be negative.

questions.question_text: A train travels the first 30 km at 60 km/h and the next 30 km at 40 km/h. What is its average speed for the entire journey?

options.label: A
options.text: 50 km/h

options.label: B
options.text: 48 km/h

options.label: C
options.text: 45 km/h

options.label: D
options.text: 55 km/h

questions.key_concept: Calculating average speed (total distance/total time).

questions.question_text: How does instantaneous speed fundamentally differ from average speed?

options.label: A
options.text: Instantaneous speed is always lower than average speed.

options.label: B
options.text: Instantaneous speed is the speed at a specific instant, while average speed is over a time interval.

options.label: C
options.text: Instantaneous speed is a vector, average speed is a scalar.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no difference; they are always equal.

questions.key_concept: Instantaneous vs average speed

questions.question_text: Why is it necessary to use the concept of 'instantaneous speed' for a car moving in city traffic?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the car's speed is constant.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the car's speed changes continuously, and we need to know its speed at a particular moment (e.g., from the speedometer).

options.label: C
options.text: Because the average speed is always zero in city traffic.

options.label: D
options.text: Because instantaneous speed is easier to calculate than average speed.

questions.key_concept: Need for instantaneous speed in variable motion.

questions.question_text: Velocity is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: Distance travelled per unit time.

options.label: B
options.text: Speed in a specified direction or the rate of change of displacement.

options.label: C
options.text: The total path length divided by time.

options.label: D
options.text: Change in speed per unit time.

questions.key_concept: Definition of velocity

questions.question_text: Two bodies have the same velocity only if they have the same:

options.label: A
options.text: Speed

options.label: B
options.text: Direction of motion

options.label: C
options.text: Both speed and direction

options.label: D
options.text: Mass

questions.key_concept: Velocity is specified by speed and direction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following motions is a trap where speed is constant but velocity is not uniform?

options.label: A
options.text: A car moving on a straight road with constant speed.

options.label: B
options.text: A freely falling stone.

options.label: C
options.text: A satellite moving in a circular orbit with constant speed.

options.label: D
options.text: A train starting from rest and moving in a straight line.

questions.key_concept: Uniform speed does not imply uniform velocity if direction changes.

questions.question_text: A car travels 60 km due east in 1 hour and then 80 km due north in the next 2 hours. What is the magnitude of its average velocity for the entire journey?

options.label: B
options.text: 50 km/h

options.label: D
options.text: 140 km/h

questions.key_concept: Average velocity = total displacement / total time. Displacement = sqrt(60^2+80^2)=100 km. Time=3h.

questions.question_text: In which scenario is the average velocity of a body zero, but its average speed is not zero?

options.label: A
options.text: A body moving in a straight line with constant speed.

options.label: B
options.text: A body thrown vertically upwards and returning to the thrower's hand.

options.label: C
options.text: A body moving in a circle with constant speed.

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

questions.key_concept: Average velocity is zero when displacement is zero, but distance is not.

questions.question_text: Why is it said that velocity determines the direction of motion of a body, while acceleration does not?

options.label: A
options.text: Because acceleration is always in the direction of motion.

options.label: B
options.text: Because velocity tells us the body's instantaneous direction. Acceleration tells us how velocity changes; it could be in the same direction (speeding up) or opposite (slowing down).

options.label: C
options.text: Because acceleration is a scalar quantity.

options.label: D
options.text: Because direction is only associated with displacement, not velocity.

questions.key_concept: Velocity vs Acceleration in determining direction.

questions.question_text: Acceleration is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: The total distance covered per unit time.

options.label: B
options.text: The rate of change of velocity with time.

options.label: C
options.text: The final velocity divided by time.

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in speed per second.

questions.key_concept: Definition of acceleration

questions.question_text: A negative acceleration is also called:

options.label: A
options.text: Deceleration or retardation

options.label: B
options.text: Uniform acceleration

options.label: C
options.text: Variable acceleration

options.label: D
options.text: Zero acceleration

questions.key_concept: Identification of retardation

questions.question_text: Which scenario is a trap where a body has acceleration even though its speed is constant?

options.label: A
options.text: A car moving on a straight road with increasing speed.

options.label: B
options.text: A stone falling freely under gravity.

options.label: C
options.text: A car taking a U-turn at constant speed.

options.label: D
options.text: A train coming to a halt at a station.

questions.key_concept: Acceleration occurs due to change in velocity (speed or direction).

questions.question_text: A car's velocity increases from 18 km/h to 72 km/h in 10 s. What is its acceleration in m/s²?

options.label: A
options.text: 1.5 m/s²

options.label: B
options.text: 5.4 m/s²

options.label: C
options.text: 15 m/s²

questions.key_concept: a = (v-u)/t. Convert km/h to m/s: 18 km/h = 5 m/s, 72 km/h = 20 m/s. a = (20-5)/10 = 1.5 m/s².

questions.question_text: What distinguishes uniformly accelerated motion from motion with variable acceleration?

options.label: A
options.text: In uniformly accelerated motion, speed changes; in variable acceleration, direction changes.

options.label: B
options.text: In uniformly accelerated motion, equal changes in velocity occur in equal time intervals; in variable acceleration, the rate of change of velocity is not constant.

options.label: C
options.text: Uniform acceleration is always positive, variable acceleration is always negative.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no distinction; they are the same.

questions.key_concept: Uniform vs variable acceleration definition.

questions.question_text: If the velocity of a body is decreasing at a constant rate, why is its acceleration said to be constant and negative?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the body is moving backwards.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the change in velocity (v-u) per second is constant and negative, resulting in a constant negative value for a = (v-u)/t.

options.label: C
options.text: Because acceleration is defined as decrease in speed.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the body will eventually come to rest.

questions.key_concept: Constant retardation implies constant negative acceleration.

questions.question_text: What is acceleration due to gravity?

options.label: A
options.text: The force with which Earth attracts a body.

options.label: B
options.text: The acceleration produced in a freely falling body due to Earth's gravitational attraction.

options.label: C
options.text: The velocity acquired by a body falling from a height.

options.label: D
options.text: The rate at which a body slows down when thrown upwards.

questions.key_concept: Definition of 'g'

questions.question_text: What is the approximate average value of acceleration due to gravity (g) on Earth's surface?

options.label: A
options.text: 9.8 cm/s²

options.label: B
options.text: 98 m/s²

options.label: C
options.text: 9.8 m/s²

options.label: D
options.text: 1 m/s²

questions.key_concept: Numerical value of g

questions.question_text: Which statement about 'g' is a trap?

options.label: A
options.text: 'g' is a constant value everywhere on Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: 'g' is maximum at the poles and minimum at the equator.

options.label: C
options.text: 'g' decreases with altitude.

options.label: D
options.text: For a freely falling body, a = +g.

questions.key_concept: 'g' varies with location, it is not a universal constant.

questions.question_text: A ball is dropped from a height. What will be its velocity after 3 seconds of fall? (Take g = 10 m/s²)

options.label: A
options.text: 10 m/s

options.label: B
options.text: 30 m/s

options.label: C
options.text: 45 m/s

questions.key_concept: v = u + gt, with u=0, t=3s, g=10 m/s².

questions.question_text: How does the acceleration due to gravity ('g') acting on a heavy object compare to that acting on a light object when both are dropped in vacuum?

options.label: A
options.text: 'g' is greater for the heavier object.

options.label: B
options.text: 'g' is smaller for the heavier object.

options.label: C
options.text: 'g' is the same for both objects.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the shape of the objects.

questions.key_concept: 'g' is independent of mass in vacuum.

questions.question_text: Why does a stone and a feather, dropped simultaneously from the same height in a vacuum tube, reach the ground at the same time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have the same weight.

options.label: B
options.text: Because in vacuum, there is no air resistance or buoyancy, so both fall with the same acceleration 'g'.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the stone has less air resistance than the feather.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the force of gravity is stronger on the stone.

questions.key_concept: Explanation of free fall in vacuum.

questions.question_text: On a displacement-time graph, what does the slope of the line represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Acceleration

options.label: B
options.text: Distance

options.label: C
options.text: Velocity

options.label: D
options.text: Time

questions.key_concept: Slope of s-t graph gives velocity.

questions.question_text: Which type of displacement-time graph indicates that the body is stationary?

options.label: A
options.text: A straight line with a positive slope.

options.label: B
options.text: A straight line parallel to the time axis.

options.label: C
options.text: A curve sloping upwards.

options.label: D
options.text: A straight line with a negative slope.

questions.key_concept: Zero slope (parallel to time axis) means zero velocity (rest).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an IMPOSSIBLE displacement-time graph?

options.label: A
options.text: A straight line parallel to the displacement axis (vertical line).

options.label: B
options.text: A straight line with a positive slope.

options.label: C
options.text: A curve.

options.label: D
options.text: A straight line with a negative slope.

questions.key_concept: A vertical line would imply infinite velocity.

questions.question_text: From the given displacement-time graph (straight line from (0,0) to (5,50)), what is the velocity of the body?

options.label: A
options.text: 5 m/s

options.label: B
options.text: 10 m/s

options.label: C
options.text: 50 m/s

questions.question_text: How can you distinguish between motion with uniform velocity and motion with variable velocity using a displacement-time graph?

options.label: A
options.text: Uniform velocity gives a straight line; variable velocity gives a curve.

options.label: B
options.text: Uniform velocity gives a curve; variable velocity gives a straight line.

options.label: C
options.text: Both give straight lines, but with different slopes.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not possible to distinguish from this graph.

questions.key_concept: s-t graph shape for uniform vs variable velocity.

questions.question_text: In a displacement-time graph, a straight line has a negative slope. What does this tell you about the body's motion?

options.label: A
options.text: The body is moving away from the starting point with decreasing speed.

options.label: B
options.text: The body is moving towards the starting point with constant velocity.

options.label: C
options.text: The body is accelerating in the negative direction.

options.label: D
options.text: The body is at rest.

questions.key_concept: Negative slope indicates constant negative velocity (motion towards origin).

questions.question_text: On a velocity-time graph, what does the slope of the line represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Displacement

options.label: B
options.text: Acceleration

options.label: C
options.text: Distance

options.label: D
options.text: Speed

questions.key_concept: Slope of v-t graph gives acceleration.

questions.question_text: Which type of velocity-time graph indicates uniform acceleration?

options.label: A
options.text: A straight line parallel to the time axis.

options.label: B
options.text: A straight line inclined to the time axis.

options.label: C
options.text: A curve.

options.label: D
options.text: A straight line parallel to the velocity axis.

questions.key_concept: Constant slope (straight line) means constant acceleration.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an IMPOSSIBLE velocity-time graph?

options.label: A
options.text: A straight line parallel to the velocity axis (vertical line).

options.label: B
options.text: A straight line with a positive slope.

options.label: C
options.text: A horizontal line.

options.label: D
options.text: A straight line with a negative slope.

questions.key_concept: A vertical line would imply infinite acceleration.

questions.question_text: From a velocity-time graph, the area under the curve between two time instants gives:

options.label: A
options.text: Acceleration in that interval.

options.label: B
options.text: Change in velocity in that interval.

options.label: C
options.text: Displacement in that interval.

options.label: D
options.text: Average velocity in that interval.

questions.key_concept: Area under v-t graph gives displacement.

questions.question_text: For a body in motion, how does the area under the velocity-time graph above the time axis compare to the area below the time axis in terms of displacement?

options.label: A
options.text: Area above gives positive displacement; area below gives negative displacement.

options.label: B
options.text: Area above gives distance; area below gives displacement.

options.label: C
options.text: Both areas give positive displacement.

options.label: D
options.text: Area above gives acceleration; area below gives retardation.

questions.key_concept: Sign of area in v-t graph indicates direction of displacement.

questions.question_text: A velocity-time graph is a horizontal line on the positive velocity axis. What can be concluded about the body's acceleration and displacement over time?

options.label: A
options.text: Acceleration is zero; displacement increases linearly with time.

options.label: B
options.text: Acceleration is constant and positive; displacement is constant.

options.label: C
options.text: Acceleration is zero; displacement is constant.

options.label: D
options.text: Acceleration is constant and negative; displacement decreases.

questions.key_concept: Horizontal v-t line: a=0, v=constant => s = v*t (linear increase).

concepts.concept_name: Equations of Uniformly Accelerated Motion (Derivation and Application)

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the first equation of motion?

options.label: A
options.text: v = u + at

options.label: B
options.text: S = ut + ½ at²

options.label: C
options.text: v² = u² + 2aS

options.label: D
options.text: S = ½ (u+v)t

questions.key_concept: First equation: v = u + at

questions.question_text: Which equation of motion does NOT involve time 't' explicitly?

options.label: A
options.text: v = u + at

options.label: B
options.text: S = ut + ½ at²

options.label: C
options.text: v² = u² + 2aS

options.label: D
options.text: S = ½ (u+v)t

questions.key_concept: Third equation: v² = u² + 2aS

questions.question_text: A common mistake is to use S = ut + ½ at² when acceleration is not constant. What is the correct condition for using this equation?

options.label: A
options.text: Motion must be in a straight line.

options.label: B
options.text: Initial velocity must be zero.

options.label: C
options.text: Acceleration must be uniform (constant).

options.label: D
options.text: Final velocity must be known.

questions.key_concept: Equations of motion are valid only for uniform acceleration.

questions.question_text: A body starts from rest and moves with a uniform acceleration of 2 m/s². What is its velocity after 5 s?

options.label: B
options.text: 10 m/s

options.label: C
options.text: 25 m/s

options.label: D
options.text: 50 m/s

questions.key_concept: v = u + at; u=0, a=2 m/s², t=5 s => v=10 m/s.

questions.question_text: How does the equation S = ut + ½ at² simplify for a body starting from rest?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes S = ½ at²

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes S = ut

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes S = vt - ½ at²

options.label: D
options.text: It does not simplify.

questions.key_concept: When u=0, S = ½ at².

questions.question_text: Why is the equation v² = u² + 2aS particularly useful when the time of travel is unknown?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the shortest equation.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it relates velocity, acceleration, and displacement directly without involving time.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it always gives an accurate result.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it can be used for non-uniform acceleration.

questions.key_concept: Utility of the third equation of motion.

questions.question_text: For a body thrown vertically upwards, what is the acceleration acting on it? (Take upward as positive)

options.label: C
options.text: Zero

questions.key_concept: Upward motion: a = -g (retardation).

questions.question_text: At the highest point of its trajectory, the velocity of a body thrown vertically upwards is:

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum

options.label: B
options.text: Equal to the initial velocity

options.label: C
options.text: Zero

options.label: D
options.text: Equal to g

questions.key_concept: Velocity zero at maximum height.

questions.question_text: Which statement about motion under gravity is a common trap?

options.label: A
options.text: The time taken to rise to the highest point equals the time taken to fall back.

options.label: B
options.text: The velocity with which it returns to the thrower's hand is equal to the initial velocity.

options.label: C
options.text: The acceleration is zero at the highest point.

options.label: D
options.text: The acceleration remains constant throughout the motion (if air resistance is neglected).

questions.key_concept: Acceleration is -g throughout, even at the highest point.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upwards with a velocity of 49 m/s. Taking g = 9.8 m/s², calculate the maximum height reached.
questions.key_concept: Using v² = u² + 2aS; at top, v=0, a=-g, S=H. H = u²/(2g) = (49²)/(2*9.8) = 122.5 m.

questions.question_text: How does the distance covered in the nth second for a freely falling body (starting from rest) compare to that covered in the (n-1)th second?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the same.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases by g (approximately 9.8 m).

options.label: C
options.text: It decreases by g.

options.label: D
options.text: It is n times greater.

questions.key_concept: Distance in nth second: S_nth = u + (g/2)(2n-1). For u=0, difference between consecutive seconds is g.

questions.question_text: Why does a body, projected vertically upwards, take the same time to go up and come back down to the point of projection?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the distance travelled upwards and downwards is the same.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the magnitude of acceleration is constant (g) and the displacement is zero for the round trip.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the speed decreases at a constant rate 'g' during ascent and increases at the same rate 'g' during descent over the same distance.

options.label: D
options.text: Because gravity pulls it down with a force proportional to its mass.

questions.key_concept: Symmetry in time for vertical motion under constant g.
